Executive Summary
Sand Springs Water Treatment Plant
Risk Management Plan
June 2017 Update

The Sand Springs Water Treatment Plant (SSWTP) uses chlorine (Cl2) to disinfect processed
water and sustain the quality of the water throughout the distribution system. The quantity of Cl2
maintained on-site for this purpose exceeds the threshold limit as defined by the Environmental
Protection Agency (EPA), 40 CFR, Part 68, under Section 112 ( r ) of the Clean Air Act.

The City of Sand Springs and its facilities are devoted to the prevention of accidental releases of
hazardous chemicals. This is evident by the established training procedures utilized by the City
personnel.

The SSWTP supplies drinking water to both Sand Springs residents and rural water districts.
The treatment process is designed for a production capacity of 10 mgd. Normal daily operation
treats 4 to 6 mgd. Chlorine is used to inactivate pathogenic organisms in the treated water before
distribution and to maintain a chlorine residual within the distribution system to protect the water
quality. The chlorine supply is pulled into the process from one-ton containers under a vacuum.
The presence of the vacuum prevents gas from escaping into the atmosphere incase of potential
failure downstream of the vacuum regulator. This vacuum feed begins at the regulators, which
are mounted directly to the ton containers, eliminating gaseous pressure piping in the system.
The gas is then mixed into a water solution and fed into the treatment.

The impact areas for both the worst case and alternate release scenarios were based on the results
from the software program ALHOA developed by NOAA. The worst case release scenario
considered a one-ton release within a 10-minute period. This resulted in a 2.6-mile radius, which
could impact an estimated population of 17,063 persons. No active or inactive mitigation was
considered in this scenario.

The alternate release scenario was based on a gas relea

se created by improper sealing of a
leaking or broken valve. No gas is able to escape downstream of the regulators due to the
vacuum feed method from the one-ton container since the rest of the system operates either
under a vacuum or in a solution. A valve break at the container could result in a release rate of
15 lbs/min of Cl2. The impact area of this release was determined by ALHOA to have a radius
of 1009 yards (0.6 miles), and approximately 542 people within the release impacted area.
The chlorine system components at the plant comply with one or more of the following
standards: AWWA Standards, Oklahoma Department of Environmental Quality Regulations,
ASTM Standards, ANSI Standards, and ASME Standards. In addition, consistent maintenance
and regular training sessions will minimize the potential for a toxic release.

If a release were to occur, then the chlorine gas detectors would notify plant by sounding an
alarm. For a small leak with no potential safety or health hazard, plant personnel would stop the
leak using personal protective equipment (PPE). If unable to stop the leak or if the leak is substantial posing health or safety hazard, then City personnel would contact local City of sand
Springs Fir Department, Advance Chemical, police and other city staff respectively. Other
regulatory agencies would be contacted as required. The local Emergency Planning and
Response Team work with plant personnel to minimize the impact of the release by training and
initiating drills to verify preparedness as drilled in accordance with the county emergency
response procedure manual.
